author: By Jessica Grose
title: When Reproductive Choice Is a Family Value
description: What it’s like to be a second-generation director of a North Carolina abortion clinic.
content: Calla Hales said she wore her bulletproof vest to work on Saturday for the first time in a long time. Hales is the executive director of A Preferred Women’s Health Center, a clinic that provides abortion care in Charlotte, N.C., and has branches in Raleigh, N.C.; Augusta, Ga.; and Atlanta. She’s always worried about her safety, because of the endless stream of threats that abortion providers get. But when I talked to her last week, Hales was dubious about how useful the vest is: It doesn’t cover her entire body so she knows it won’t necessarily save her life.

description: Ben & Jerry’s, the American ice cream maker owned by Unilever, angered many Israelis last year when it pledged to discontinue sales in the occupied West Bank.
content: JERUSALEM — Unilever said on Wednesday that it had sold the Israeli arm of the ice cream maker Ben & Jerry’s, nearly a year after Ben & Jerry’s set off a fury in Israel by saying it would stop selling its products in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

content: The National Weather Service issues two types of tornado alerts: warnings and watches. Both can be broadcast on local news, in phone alerts, on the service’s website or on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s weather radio. Tornado sirens are also used in some communities, but their meanings vary across the country.

description: A reluctance by some liberal district attorneys to bring criminal charges against abortion providers is already complicating the legal landscape in some states.
content: HOUSTON — Deep rifts have emerged among the hundreds of elected district attorneys who will be charged with enforcing the expanding restrictions on abortion, creating a Balkanized new legal system within states that are banning the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Hochul and Zeldin Will Face Off in the Fall
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul cruised to victory in the Democratic race but could face a tough fight in November.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’re following two stories — the results in the New York primaries for governor, and Ghislaine Maxwell’s 20-year prison sentence for serving as Jeffrey Epstein’s enabler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Tina Peters, an indicted county clerk, loses the G.O.P. primary for Colorado secretary of state to Pam Anderson.
description: Ms. Peters, who has become a celebrity in far-right circles, was beaten by Ms. Anderson, a longtime election official who has been a vocal opponent of misinformation about the 2020 contest.
content: Tina Peters, a county clerk who has been charged with seven felonies related to a scheme to surreptitiously copy sensitive voting data, lost her bid for the Republican nomination for Colorado secretary of state on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Use That Everyday A.I. in Your Pocket
description: Artificial intelligence powers more apps on your mobile devices than you may realize. Here’s how to take advantage of the technology — or turn it off.
content: Virtual assistants usually hog the spotlight when it comes to talk of artificial intelligence software on smartphones and tablets. But Apple’s Siri, Google Assistant, Samsung’s Bixby and company aren’t the only tools using machine learning to make life easier — other common programs use the technology, too. Here’s a quick tour through some common A.I.-driven apps and how you can manage them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Hamby and Michael Forsythe
title: Behind the Scenes, McKinsey Guided Companies at the Center of the Opioid Crisis
description: The consulting firm offered clients “in-depth experience in narcotics,” from poppy fields to pills more powerful than Purdue’s OxyContin.
content: In patches of rural Appalachia and the Rust Belt, the health authorities were sounding alarms that a powerful painkiller called Opana had become the drug of choice among people abusing prescription pills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: After Rapes by Russian Soldiers, a Painful Quest for Justice
description: Women who were attacked in a village near Kyiv yearn for justice. “I want them to be punished,” said one victim. But Ukrainian officials face daunting challenges in prosecuting such crimes.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Every day, Viktoriya has to walk past the house where she was raped by a Russian soldier the same age as her teenage son.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Left to Be Found
description: Two women share their adoption stories — one a daughter, and the other a mother.
content: Yvonne Liu knew from a young age that she was adopted, but she didn’t know the details. All she knew was that she had been left by her birth mother in a busy stairwell in Hong Kong. It wasn’t until she was 30, on the night before a critical surgery, that she was given a handwritten note in Chinese that transformed her understanding of where she had come from.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bernard Stolar, Influential Video Game Executive, Dies at 75
description: He worked on the original PlayStation at Sony, then brought Sega’s Dreamcast to the market in the late 1990s.
content: Bernard Stolar, who as an executive at Sony and then at Sega of America played an important role in the development and marketing of the video game consoles of the 1990s, including the original PlayStation and Sega’s Dreamcast, died on June 22 in Los Angeles. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: Naked No More: A TV Rodent Teaches Families About Tolerance
description: A new adaptation of the Mo Willems book “Naked Mole Rat Gets Dressed” uses animation and rock songs to tell a story about self-expression and acceptance.
content: Mo Willems’s picture books often feature committed nonconformists — not the human kind, but the animal variety. Over the last two decades, he has invented a pigeon that’s determined to drive a bus, a pig that wants to fly and a cookie-baking dinosaur that doesn’t care that she’s extinct. Now, one of Willems’s most gently adventurous creatures is about to shed its inhibitions on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: What can I do now to prepare for a future hurricane?
description: Make a solid plan, and communicate it to your family well before a storm comes nearby.
content: The most important thing to do now, before any hurricane warnings, is to make a family plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Consumer spending was weaker than reported, a bad sign for the economy.
description: Revised first-quarter figures show spending rose only 0.5 percent, a slowdown from the 0.6 percent growth recorded in the final quarter of 2021.
content: Consumer spending was weaker in early 2022 than previously believed, a sign that cracks may be forming in a crucial pillar of the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins, J. David Goodman and Miriam Jordan
title: Truck Carrying Dead Migrants Passed Through U.S. Checkpoint
description: Border Patrol officials say truck traffic is too voluminous to check every vehicle at the dozens of immigration checkpoints on roadways near the border.
content: SAN ANTONIO — A tractor-trailer that ended up in San Antonio with more than 50 dead or dying migrants passed through a federal immigration checkpoint inside the United States without being inspected, a top Mexican official said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Serena Williams, Closer to the End Than the Middle, Still Believes
description: A second consecutive first-round exit at Wimbledon leaves the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion looking human, but suggesting she has more tennis left to play.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Most likely, it was not truly the end. Chances are there will be some more tennis, maybe even another major tournament at the end of the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Michael D. Shear
title: NATO formally invites Finland and Sweden to join the alliance.
description: The historic deal underscores how the war in Ukraine has backfired for President Vladimir V. Putin.
content: MADRID — NATO leaders on Wednesday formally invited Finland and Sweden to join the alliance, one day after Turkey dropped its objections to their membership, clearing the way for what would be one of the most significant expansions of the alliance in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Building Owner Charged in Fire That Killed a Philadelphia Firefighter
description: The man was charged with two counts related to arson after he fled to Jordan and was arrested on his return to the U.S., the authorities said.
content: A Philadelphia man has been charged with intentionally setting fire to a three-story building he owned, causing the structure to collapse on top of firefighters and killing one of them, the authorities said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: What Makes Taika Waititi Run and Run and Run?
description: The “Thor: Love and Thunder” director can’t say no — to starring in “Our Flag Means Death,” making a soccer movie, writing a “Star Wars” idea, adapting Roald Dahl. For starters.
content: Even when your job is to dream up the interplanetary adventures of a Norse god, you might still want to run off and play pirates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Darren Bailey, a far-right state senator, will be the Republican nominee for Illinois governor.
description: Mr. Bailey overcame a well-funded rival backed by the state’s Republican leaders with some unusual help: tens of millions of dollars from Gov. J.B. Pritzker, a billionaire Democrat.
content: PEORIA, Ill. — Darren Bailey, a far-right state senator who was the beneficiary of an extraordinary effort by Democrats to help his candidacy, has won the Republican primary for governor in Illinois.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Zeldin’s Anti-Abortion Stance May Affect the N.Y. Governor’s Race
description: Representative Lee Zeldin, the Republican candidate for governor, said the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade was a victory for family, life and the Constitution.
content: The confetti was still falling at her Democratic primary victory party Tuesday night when Gov. Kathy Hochul rolled out a general election warning: If her Republican opponent wins in November, he could follow the Supreme Court’s lead and curtail New Yorkers’ abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gov. Hochul Cruises to Democratic Primary Win in New York

content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York took a crucial step toward winning a full term on Tuesday, easily fending off a pair of spirited primary challengers and cementing her status as the state’s top Democrat less than a year after she unexpectedly took office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: R. Kelly’s 30-year sentence was the end of a long downfall for the former superstar.
description: R. Kelly, the former R&B singer who had long escaped criminal penalties despite decades of sexual misconduct allegations, was sentenced to 30 years in prison Wednesday for sex trafficking and racketeering.
content: R. Kelly, the former R&B singer who had long escaped criminal penalties despite decades of sexual misconduct allegations, was sentenced to 30 years in prison Wednesday for sex trafficking and racketeering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Steven Erlanger
title: The U.S. moves closer to selling F-16s to Turkey.

content: MADRID — The United States on Wednesday signaled a new willingness to sell upgraded F-16 fighter jets to Turkey, moving closer to satisfying the ally’s longstanding request a day after Turkey dropped its opposition to efforts by Finland and Sweden to join the NATO alliance.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Substack is laying off 14% of its staff.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Artists Scrutinize a Collector’s Nazi Family Past

content: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — In early June, the Julia Stoschek Collection, one of the world’s pre-eminent private institutions for media art, premiered an ambitious new show here to celebrate its 15th anniversary: “Worldbuilding,” an exhibition focused on the intersection between art and video gaming that features works exploring issues like transphobia, gun violence and environmental degradation.
source.name: The New York Times

content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor of this puzzle, Jared Goudsmit, on making his New York Times Crossword debut! But if you’re stuck trying to solve this puzzle and think you’re never going to crack it, think again.

source.name: The New York Times

title: 20 Men Convicted in November 2015 Paris Terrorist Attack
description: The verdict capped a 10-month trial on the Islamic State rampage of November 2015 that killed 130 people, traumatized the country and still shapes French politics.
content: PARIS — Twenty men were convicted on Wednesday for their roles in the worst Islamist terrorist attack in French history, a coordinated spree of shootings and bombings in November 2015 that killed 130 people in and near Paris and injured more than 500, leaving lasting scars on the nation’s psyche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: What does the hurricane scale tell us?
description: The five categories of the storm are related to their wind speed, but they also gives us insight to their potential for damage.
content: Hurricanes are categorized by their wind speeds on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. The scale was first developed by Herb Saffir, a structural engineer, and Bob Simpson, a meteorologist.

title: Wisconsin Court Validates a Republican Strategy to Preserve Power

content: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Wednesday effectively handed the Republican-controlled State Senate broad authority over the composition of state boards and commissions, three and a half years into the term of a Democratic governor whose duties include naming board members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: ‘Just Be Smart’: Yankees Look to Manage Workloads
description: The Yankees have one of the best rotations in baseball. Keeping it that way will involve some careful planning.

Keeping it that way, as the season grinds along, will involve careful workload management for two of the team’s brightest stars: Nestor Cortes and Luis Severino.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Democrats Are Having a Purity-Test Problem at Exactly the Wrong Time
description: “It has become too easy for people to conflate disagreements about issues with matters of identity,” one nonprofit official says.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Strugatz
title: Get a Whiff of This
description: The perfumer David Moltz has created a collection of perfumes that push boundaries.

source.name: The New York Times

title: Like a Bird on a Wire That Starts a Wildfire
description: Researchers found dozens of incidents where birds fell to the ground after being electrocuted on power lines, and sparked fires. They also proposed steps to prevent such incidents.
content: A variety of triggers can kindle wildfires on dry lands: high winds that send power lines careening into each other, stray cigarette butts, even sparks from train wheels. And, sometimes, electrocuted birds.

description: She appeared in dozens of movies and television shows in a career of more than 30 years. The police said they believed she died in a drowning accident.

title: What do I need to do to clean up safely after a hurricane?
description: Document damage and clear hazards with adequate protection.
content: Avoid driving through or walking through floodwaters, which can be electrically charged from downed or underground power lines; contain debris like glass, dead animals or even poisonous snakes; or be contaminated with sewage and hazardous chemicals. Just six inches of moving water can knock down a person, and a foot of fast-moving water can destabilize a vehicle.

title: Is the Supreme Court Facing a Legitimacy Crisis?

content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

title: No One Told Me Mac Salad Could Be This Good
description: A staple of the plate lunch in Hawaii is lifted by a bit of heat and a tangy note.
content: The water was green-blue off He‘eia Kea Pier, that shade of blue with light sinking through it. I grew up on the Hawaiian island of Oahu, but this was somewhere I’d never been, although it was only a 40-minute drive from my mother’s house. There’s a joke that you can spend your life here and never go to another island, or even to the other side of your own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kaminer
title: House Hunting in Ecuador: An Andes Retreat Outside Cuenca for $550,000
description: While Ecuadoreans power the market in greater Cuenca, the city has long attracted retirees with its low cost of living and high quality of life.
content: Perched at the eastern edge of El Cajas National Park, a UNESCO-designated biosphere reserve, this contemporary home sits on four undulating acres outside of Cuenca, Ecuador’s third-largest city.

author: By Julie Weed
title: Go North for Active Days and Appetizing Nights
description: The Pacific Northwest’s lesser-known jewel, Bellingham, Wash., offers world-class scenery, sculpture and seafood within easy reach of Seattle.
content: You can get from Seattle to Bellingham, Wash., by driving 90 miles straight up the interstate, but you shouldn’t. The best route to this small city tucked where the mighty Cascade mountain range meets the sea can be more scenic and pleasurable. Veer off Interstate 5 about 15 miles south of Bellingham to make the final approach via Chuckanut Drive, one of the state’s more than 20 official Scenic Byways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pelosi Received Communion at Vatican After Meeting With Pope
description: The sacrament has become a political issue, with conservative American bishops like House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s own priest, who has said he will deny her the sacrament until she stops publicly supporting abortion rights.
content: ROME — U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, an avid defender of abortion rights, met privately with Pope Francis on Wednesday and received communion from a priest during a papal Mass at St. Peter’s Basilica, according to an attendee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: New York Files Lawsuits Against a Flood of ‘Ghost Guns’
description: The legal complaints are the first to be brought by officials under a state law intended to hold firearm manufacturers accountable for gun violence.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Even the ‘Good Fires’ Can Now Turn Disastrous
description: Climate change hasn’t made all prescribed burns unsafe, but more care needs to be taken in starting them, and even then, risk cannot be eliminated entirely.
content: It is striking how often fire ecologists and climate scientists, when asked about conditions across the American West, describe half the nation as a “tinderbox.” The West is currently experiencing its worst drought in 1,200 years, which means that the last time the region received as little water as it has in recent years, the continent as a whole probably had a population of just a few million; today the West alone is home to almost 80 million. California’s spring was the most arid in its recorded history, which stretches back 125 years, when the state was home to one million, not 40 million. These are conditions that fire loves, and much of the flammable West is still months from its seasonal peak.
source.name: The New York Times

content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol issued a subpoena Wednesday for the testimony of Pat A. source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It is not at all safe’: Cities across Ukraine suffer a steady stream of civilian casualties.

title: Trump Aides Watch Testimony and Brace for Damage

title: With $440 Million, a New Arts Foundation Spreads the Wealth

content: New foundations spring up all the time, but rarely on the scale of the Ruth Foundation for the Arts, which was established this year and announces its first grants this week.

title: Philippines Orders Rappler to Shut Down

content: The Philippine government has again ordered that Rappler, the news website co-founded by Maria Ressa, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, be shut down for violating foreign ownership rules, the latest blow against press freedom in the country.

author: By Maggie Haberman, Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Key Questions Posed by Cassidy Hutchinson’s Testimony
description: The former White House aide’s appearance before the House Jan. 6 committee raised a host of issues sure to be topics of further inquiry.
content: For two hours, Cassidy Hutchinson, a former White House aide, laid out a devastating account on Tuesday of former President Donald J. Trump’s actions and state of mind on Jan. 6, 2021, and in the days leading up to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Pennington
title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
content: At 76 years old, Judy Fog is one of the fittest people her daughter knows. Take, for instance, her VO2 max — a common fitness metric that measures how much oxygen one can absorb while exercising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Johnny Diaz
title: Americans Who Died at Bahamas Resort Were Poisoned by Carbon Monoxide
description: The authorities said they did not suspect foul play when the tourists were found unresponsive in two villas at a Sandals resort on Great Exuma Island in May.
content: Three Americans who were found dead under mysterious circumstances at a resort in the Bahamas in May died of carbon monoxide poisoning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.4 Million Homes in New York, Illinois and Massachusetts
description: An 1873 Victorian in Hudson, a three-bedroom townhouse in Chicago and a 19th-century home in Gloucester.
content: This colorful house, a few blocks from the Hudson Amtrak station, has a wide front porch, ideal for watching the neighborhood’s activities. A coffee shop, a restaurant serving farm-to-table Tuscan food and an ice-cream parlor are all within a five-minute walk, and downtown Hudson’s dining and shopping is about half a mile away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Revisiting Justice Stephen Breyer’s Curious (and Strangely Timed) Defense of the Court
description: In a book published last year, Breyer depicted the Supreme Court as an apolitical institution that sticks to its guiding principles.
content: There’s something undeniably ironic about a Supreme Court justice publishing a book defending the court as unflaggingly dedicated to its guiding principles and then, less than a year later, signing on to a dissent that explicitly lays out how “this court betrays its guiding principles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: When should I evacuate?
description: Knowing the difference between a hurricane warning and a hurricane watch can help you better decide when to stay and when to leave during a storm.
content: Knowing the difference between a hurricane warning and a hurricane watch can help you better decide when to stay and when to leave during a storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: What is a storm surge? Why is it so dangerous?
description: A storm surge is an abnormal rise of water generated by a storm, over and above the predicted astronomical tides.
content: It’s no secret that tropical storms and hurricanes produce damaging winds and unleash heavy rains that can lead to fatal flooding. But what might be less obvious is that the storm surges they produce can be equally destructive and are often the greatest threat to life and property along coasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rina Raphael
title: TikTok Is Flooded With Health Myths. These Creators Are Pushing Back.
description: Meet the medical experts fighting bogus science, one “stitch” at a time.
content: “I’m willing to bet you know at least one girl that’s using steroids every single day,” starts a young man in a TikTok video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Mother and Son Are Charged With Murder in Death of 7-Year-Old Bronx Girl
description: Julissia Batties, who was beaten to death, had a case file with the city’s child welfare agency from the day she was born.
content: For nearly a year, law enforcement officials labored over the investigation into the murder of a 7-year-old girl named Julissia Batties, who was found fatally beaten at her mother’s apartment in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: A Drive to St. Michaels Leads to Historical Homes and Bay Views
description: The waterfront town on Maryland’s Eastern Shore provides a timeless getaway for nature seekers and admirers of early American history and architecture.
content: With Memorial Day weekend upon me, I packed a bag and drove east, following a 80-mile path trodden for decades by fellow Washington residents looking for calmer seasonal destinations. After crossing the Chesapeake Bay Bridge and heading south on windy back roads, I finally stepped out in St. Michaels, Md., a waterfront destination often celebrated as one of the crown jewels of Maryland’s Eastern Shore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Betty Rowland, One of Burlesque's Last Queens, Dies at 106
description: Known as “the Red Headed Ball of Fire,” she began performing at age 14, became a headliner on two coasts, and outlived most of her peers.
content: She was known as the “Red Headed Ball of Fire,” a title given her for her stature — she was a diminutive 5-foot-1 — and her fiery hair. She found the moniker, which was often shortened to “Ball of Fire,” corny. But Betty Rowland was a burlesque queen nonetheless. A headliner in the racy variety shows’ glory years in the 1930s and ’40s, she worked well into the ’50s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: R. Kelly, R&B Star Who Long Evaded Justice, Is Sentenced to 30 Years
description: The prison term marks the culmination of Mr. Kelly’s stunning downfall. In court, the women he victimized gave wrenching accounts. “I don’t know if I’ll ever be whole,” one said.
content: Thirty-one years ago, R. Kelly, a budding R&B artist from Chicago in his mid-20s, was signed to his first major record label. Around the same time, he began having sex with a 15-year-old girl, according to her subsequent lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: N.Y. Assembly Democrats Largely Repel Challenges From the Left
description: Long-tenured incumbents appeared likely to retain their seats, though an activist was ahead in a Hudson Valley race.
content: In the Democratic primary for the New York State Assembly, a slate of left-leaning insurgents — running with the backing of the progressive Working Families Party and Democratic Socialists of America — had hoped to unseat a group of long-serving incumbents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norman Eisen
title: Cassidy Hutchinson Changes Everything
description: Her testimony delivered shocking and consequential revelations, but they have hardly been the only ones.
content: Tuesday’s testimony by Cassidy Hutchinson, an aide to Mark Meadows, the final chief of staff for President Donald Trump, snapped attention back to the Jan. 6 committee in a striking finale to the first stretch of the hearings, which are expected to resume in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Lee Zeldin Captures Republican Primary for N.Y. Governor
description: Mr. Zeldin, a Long Island congressman, will try to become the first Republican to win a statewide race in 20 years when he faces Gov. Kathy Hochul in November.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Representative Lee M. Zeldin, a four-term congressman from Long Island, won the Republican primary for governor of New York on Tuesday, fending off a spirited challenge in a four-way race, and advancing to a general election where his party hopes to break a two-decade losing streak in statewide races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Lauren Hirsch
title: Spirit Airlines calls off a Thursday reckoning on Frontier’s bid.
description: Spirit said it would continue to talk with both Frontier and JetBlue, putting off a shareholder vote until July 8.
content: On the eve of a planned shareholder meeting on an acquisition by Frontier Airlines, Spirit Airlines said Wednesday evening that it was putting off the vote and would continue to talk to both Frontier and a rival suitor, JetBlue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Michael D. Shear
title: A More Muscular NATO Emerges as West Confronts Russia and China
description: It is a fundamental shift for a military alliance born in the Cold War and scrambling to respond to a newly reshaped world.
content: MADRID — Faced with a newly aggressive Russia, NATO leaders on Wednesday outlined a muscular new vision that names Moscow as the military alliance’s primary adversary but also, for the first time, declares China to be a strategic “challenge.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida
title: Read Your Way Through Lisbon
description: The award-winning Portuguese novelist Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida recommends books to help readers get to know Portugal’s vibrant capital, and spots to read them if you go.
content: Lisbon has long been marked by a certain wistfulness. Perched at the westernmost edge of Europe, it has been a place of departures as much as of arrivals, its cobblestone streets perpetually echoing with the voices of those who have passed through. That is the city captured in “Lisboa, Cidade Triste e Alegre,” a symphonic graphic poem first published in 1959 by Victor Palla and Costa Martins, whose grainy black-and-white images caught the essence of a place longing for change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon Restricts L.G.B.T.Q. Products in United Arab Emirates
description: Sales of items including flags and books were blocked in the country, where homosexuality is criminalized.
content: Amazon moved to restrict items and search results related to L.G.B.T.Q. people and issues on its website in the United Arab Emirates on Monday after receiving pressure from the government there, according to company documents viewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: A timeline of R. Kelly’s downfall, three decades in the making.
description: From the initial allegations in the 1990s to the #MeToo movement, here is a chronology of the events leading up to his sentencing.
content: Despite facing allegations of sexual misconduct stretching back more than three decades, R. Kelly did not begin to face criminal penalties for his actions until September, when he was found guilty in federal court in New York of recruiting women and underage girls and boys for sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: ‘Let the people in’
description: Trump and his top aides knew that the Jan. 6 rally was likely to turn violent.
content: How much did President Donald Trump and his top advisers know ahead of the Jan. 6 attack about the potential for violence? Until the past few weeks, the answer to that question had been unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Your Lawn Questions, Answered
description: No, mowing less often doesn’t mean more ticks. And there’s a way to get around those homeowner association rules. Read on.
content: Who knew that the lawn — a generic landscape element that we basically manage on autopilot — could be so provocative? The recent In the Garden column “Yes, You Can Do Better Than the Great American Lawn” elicited nearly 1,200 comments, and a few key themes resounded, prompting a follow-up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Sides With Veteran Hurt by Burn Pits in Iraq
description: By a 5-to-4 vote, the justices ruled that Congress can allow suits against states that discriminate against injured service members returning from conflicts.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled in favor of an Army veteran injured in Iraq who said he had been discriminated against by his employer, the state of Texas. In a 5-to-4 decision, the court said Congress was entitled to override states’ sovereign immunity, which generally protects them from lawsuits seeking money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adlan Jackson
title: The Accidental Media Critics of YouTube
description: One of the most popular genres of videos online is to comment on other videos online. Are they comedians or media critics?
content: Gary Vaynerchuk has been an internet celebrity for so long that it’s hard to know which era’s terminology to use to describe him. He was among YouTube’s earliest stars, crafting videos first for his father’s wine business and then about media and technology companies; later he started his own media company. He has been a self-help guru, publishing books about how fans could “Crush It” in their own businesses, and also something more extreme, adopting an almost televangelist-like persona as “Gary Vee.” Most recently, nonfungible tokens, or NFTs, have turned out to be a natural fit for him: He re-entered the zeitgeist last year with his own NFT projects, exhorting his young audience to join the club lest they end up among the “losers” he spends so much time denouncing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
title: Egypt Destroys Nile Houseboats, Washing Away a Living Lore
description: Divas hosted debauched salons on them, and a Nobel laureate wrote a novel on one. “They’re a kind of romantic dream,” one well-known writer said. “They’re so much a part of the heritage of Cairo.”
content: CAIRO — Rowing up to the cheerful turquoise houseboat on the Nile, a fisherman saluted the white-haired woman swaying on its deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: What should my ‘go bag’ contain?
description: Plan now for a future emergency.
content: No matter where you live, every home should have a “go bag” and a “stay bin.” The go bag is what you grab when you have to leave the house in a hurry, whether to get to the emergency room or to evacuate because of a fire or a hurricane. The stay bin is a two-week stash of essentials to be used in case you have to hunker down at home without power, water or heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Steven Erlanger
title: Why do Finland and Sweden appear headed toward swift NATO membership while Ukraine isn’t?
description: The imperative to seek NATO membership is written into Ukraine’s Constitution. But even President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that it may never happen.
content: With Finland and Sweden now racing toward NATO membership, the prospect of the two Nordic countries joining the seven-decade-old Atlantic alliance is raising a pressing question in Kyiv and beyond: Why them and not Ukraine?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and David F. Gallagher
title: The C.E.O. Silence on the Jan. 6 Hearings
description: Some business leaders say they fear retaliation for speaking out. Others point to ‘outrage fatigue.’
content: Andrew here. I want to speak with you directly this morning, much as I did after the attack on the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Who won and who lost in Tuesday’s primary elections.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York will face Representative Lee Zeldin this fall. Two Trump-endorsed candidates won key primaries in Illinois. Here’s what else happened.
content: Voters in a handful of states weighed in on key contests in Tuesday’s primaries. Here is a rundown of some of the most notable wins and losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Panel Explores Links Between Trump Allies and Extremist Groups
description: Cassidy Hutchinson, the former White House aide, testified that the former president directed his chief of staff to reach out to Michael Flynn and Roger Stone, who had ties to the Oath Keepers and the Proud Boys.
content: In their relationships with President Donald J. Trump in recent years, Roger J. Stone Jr., his longtime political adviser, and Michael T. Flynn, who was briefly his national security adviser, have followed a similar trajectory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A Canine Companion So Nice It (Maybe) Evolved Twice
description: Two different ancient wolf populations contributed DNA to modern dogs, according to a new study.
content: For years, one of the most confounding questions in science — alongside “What is dark matter?” and “Why do we sleep?” — has been one that many pet owners may have found themselves casually pondering: Where did dogs come from?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maham Javaid
title: What are magnetometers, or mags?
description: The metal detectors were at the center of Tuesday’s testimony in which Trump ordered the so-called mags to be removed so that the Jan. 6 protesters could have full access at the Capitol.
content: A portion of Tuesday’s testimony about the Capitol riot focused on magnetometers, or mags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: R. Kelly will face a second federal trial, set for August.
description: The sentencing on Wednesday does not mark the end of Mr. Kelly’s legal troubles. He could even see his time in prison lengthened after his summer trial in Chicago.
content: For the victims of the R&B singer R. Kelly, his sentencing in New York on Wednesday has been long awaited, arriving after decades of accusations of sexual and physical abuse. But Wednesday’s decision aside, the former entertainer will remain in deep legal peril — and any prison term he faces could still ultimately grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Men Are the New Men
description: Men’s wear crackled with energy as Paris surged to life, with Thom Browne and Hedi Slimane leading the charge.
content: PARIS — The importance of sticking to your guns, metaphorically and creatively speaking, was a takeaway of a resurgent men’s wear season in a tourist-mobbed and superficially booming Paris. As seemingly everywhere, prices in the French capital have skyrocketed. Hotels at all levels are sold out, and the cost of a takeout jambon beurre sandwich is nearly double that of just six months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Over 360 newspapers have closed since just before the start of the pandemic.
description: The same pace — about two closures per week — was occurring before the pandemic.
content: The pandemic has been bad for the country’s local newspapers. But maybe not as bad as some people have feared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Kujawinski
title: Where Bog, Fen and Tallgrass Prairie Unexpectedly Thrive
description: Hiding within what can seem like Chicagoland’s endless suburbs are slices of nature that make for a perfect weekend camping trip, with restaurants in easy reach.
content: One common knock against the Chicago area is that “real” nature seems far away. Apart from Lake Michigan — arguably the region’s best natural attribute — it’s sprawling suburbs and monotone fields of corn in every direction. I have subscribed to this idea for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Los Angeles County Votes to Return Beach Seized in 1924 From a Black Family
description: Ownership of the property, known as Bruce’s Beach, will be transferred to descendants of Charles and Willa Bruce, who bought the land in 1912 and built a resort.
content: Nearly 100 years after a Black couple’s beachfront property was taken away by a Southern California city, Los Angeles County voted unanimously on Tuesday to return the land to the family in what officials described as an effort to “right the wrongs of the past.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: ‘This Really Changes Things’: Three Opinion Writers on Cassidy Hutchinson’s Jan. 6 Testimony
description: Bret Stephens and Michelle Cottle answer the question: Should Trump be indicted?
content: For the past month, the House select committee on Jan. 6 has held a series of public hearings on President Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election. Yesterday it surprised all of us with some of its most stunning evidence yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: As Big Business Is Accused of Becoming ‘Woke,’ Small Business Is Looking to Go Its Own Way
description: There’s now a more conservative alternative to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
content: Big Business and the Republican Party used to be as close as Tweedledum and Tweedledee, but not anymore. On social issues such as abortion and race, the Republican Party has moved to the right while many big corporations have shifted left in an effort to please their diverse mix of employees and customers. Many companies embraced Black Lives Matter. Now a number are promising to cover travel expenses for employees who need to go to another state to get an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilaria Parogni
title: What were the worst hurricanes in history?
description: There are several different ways to think about how to measure the “worst” hurricane.
content: There are several ways one can measure the magnitude of a hurricane, including by death toll, cost and strength. However, data becomes less available the further back in time one goes, so it is difficult to name a single hurricane that holds the title of “worst.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Joy of Ham and Cheese
description: Brown-butter shrimp with hazelnuts or roasted salmon with miso rice are great options if a sandwich isn’t in your future.
content: Good morning. You miss me? I was in France for work, and if the food wasn’t as great as I’d dreamed it might be, after more than two years in the home office, at least there were ham and cheese sandwiches. Jambons beurres: warm, skinny baguettes with unsalted butter and thin slices of juicy ham and nutty Gruyère. I ate at least one of those every day I was gone, and vowed to bring the practice home with me, my 2022 song of the summer.
